name: common resource
description: A common resource is a type of good consisting of a natural or human-made resource system, whose size or characteristics makes it costly, but not impossible, to exclude potential beneficiaries from obtaining benefits from its use. Unlike pure public goods, common resources face problems of congestion or overuse, because they are rival. Examples of common resources include irrigation systems, fishing grounds, pastures, forests, water or the atmosphere.

clips.name: The Cheever Letters
clips.description: Kramer has been playing on a private golf course, but has lost his access.  He gives an impassioned speech about what it's like to play on a public course—the crowds, the brown patches of grass, etc.

tags.name: common resource
tags.description: A common resource is a type of good consisting of a natural or human-made resource system, whose size or characteristics makes it costly, but not impossible, to exclude potential beneficiaries from obtaining benefits from its use. Unlike pure public goods, common resources face problems of congestion or overuse, because they are rival. Examples of common resources include irrigation systems, fishing grounds, pastures, forests, water or the atmosphere.

source.title: Seinfeld
source.description: Seinfeld ran for nine seasons on NBC and became famous as a “show about nothing.” Basically, the show allows viewers to follow the antics of Jerry, George, Elaine, and Kramer as they move through their daily lives, often encountering interesting people or dealing with special circumstances. It is the simplicity of Seinfeld that makes it so appropriate for use in economics courses. Using these clips (as well as clips from other television shows or movies) makes economic concepts come alive, making them more real for students. Ultimately, students will start seeing economics everywhere – in other TV shows, in popular music, and most importantly, in their own lives.

clips.name: The Hamptons
clips.description: Kramer, at the beach in the Hamptons with friends, finds a rope dangling into the water and pulls up a pot full of lobsters.  He serves them for dinner that night, and his host says that he's poached them from a commercial lobsterman.  Kramer says, “What's the problem? There's plenty for everyone.”  This highlights the wedge between individual incentives and optimal social outcomes.

clips.name: The Parking Space
clips.description: George won't pay for a parking spot in a garage because he would rather find a public spot (nonexcludable) for free.  George backs into a spot while another guy comes in headfirst, resulting in the question, “Who is entitled to the space?”  Insecure property rights have led to overuse and conflict.  George says, “I was here first.”   The parking jam-up ruins street access for everyone else; everyone ends up fighting about property rights, even the police, who can't decide.

tags.name: common resource
tags.description: A common resource is a type of good consisting of a natural or human-made resource system, whose size or characteristics makes it costly, but not impossible, to exclude potential beneficiaries from obtaining benefits from its use. Unlike pure public goods, common resources face problems of congestion or overuse, because they are rival. Examples of common resources include irrigation systems, fishing grounds, pastures, forests, water or the atmosphere.

tags.name: non-excludable goods
tags.description: A non-excludable good is one for which it is impossible to prevent an individual who does not pay for that thing from enjoying the benefits of it.

tags.name: property rights
tags.description: Property rights entail the exclusive authority to determine how and by whom a particular resource is used.

tags.name: rival goods
tags.description: Rival goods are goods whose consumption by one consumer prevents simultaneous consumption by other consumers.

clips.name: The Suicide
clips.description: Jerry asks George to throw away Jerry's garbage.  George asks for $2.  Jerry offers 50 cents, and George refuses.  Jerry sets it down in front of Kramer's door and knocks.  Oddly, Kramer takes it.

tags.name: common resource
tags.description: A common resource is a type of good consisting of a natural or human-made resource system, whose size or characteristics makes it costly, but not impossible, to exclude potential beneficiaries from obtaining benefits from its use. Unlike pure public goods, common resources face problems of congestion or overuse, because they are rival. Examples of common resources include irrigation systems, fishing grounds, pastures, forests, water or the atmosphere.

tags.name: reservation wage
tags.description: A person’s reservation wage is the minimum wage necessary to entice the person into the labor market.

tags.name: supply of labor
tags.description: Labor supply  is the willingness and ability of the people within a market area to provide labor services.

clips.name: The Parking Garage
clips.description: Kramer has forgotten where he parked his car in a multi-level parking garage of a shopping mall and the gang walk around for an eternity looking for the car. Jerry needs to urinate and Kramer encourages him to do so in a dark corner where no one can see him. While doing so, he is spotted by an officer, and held in the officer's booth. Later in the episode, George is caught doing the same thing.

tags.name: common resource

tags.name: cost-benefit analysis
tags.description: Cost-benefit analysis involves, whether explicitly or implicitly, weighing the total expected costs against the total expected benefits of one or more actions in order to choose the best or most profitable option. Rational agents are assumed to never take an action for which the expected benefits are less than the expected costs.

tags.name: thinking at the margin
tags.description: From an economist's perspective, making choices involves thinking 'at the margin' - that is, making decisions based on small changes in resources. Doing so leads to the optimal decisions being made, subject to preferences, resources and informational constraints.
